an9.72:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these five emotional shackles.
an9.72:4.3: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
an9.72:4.4: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an9.72:4.5: This is the first emotional shackle.
an9.72:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …
an9.72:5.2: They’re not free of greed for form …
an9.72:5.3: They eat as much as they like until their bellies are full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying, and drowsing …
an9.72:5.4: They live the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods:
an9.72:5.5: ‘By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
an9.72:5.7: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an9.72:5.8: This is the fifth emotional shackle.
an9.72:5.9: These are the five emotional shackles.
an9.72:6.1: To give up these five emotional shackles you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
an9.72:6.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
an9.72:6.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
an9.72:6.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind …
an9.72:6.6: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
an9.72:6.7: To give up those five emotional shackles you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
